sectionTextEN: Electricity consumption in vehicles is a key aspect for assessing their energy efficiency and environmental impact. In the case of electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles, their consumption depends on factors such as battery capacity, motor type, vehicle usage, and available charging infrastructure. Pure electric vehicles (EVs) operate solely on electricity stored in rechargeable batteries. Their energy consumption is measured in kilowatt-hours per 100 kilometers (kWh/100 km), allowing for comparisons of efficiency with other transport modes. These vehicles produce no direct CO‚ÇÇ emissions, making them a more sustainable option, especially if the electricity used comes from renewable sources. On the other hand, plug-in hybrid vehicles (PHEVs) combine an electric motor with an internal combustion engine. In electric mode, they use the rechargeable battery to travel certain distances without emissions but can switch to the combustion engine when the battery is depleted. Their electric consumption varies based on the use of electric and thermal modes and access to charging points. To optimize energy consumption in these vehicles, it is advisable to: Charge batteries during off-peak hours when energy is usually cheaper and less polluting. Utilize regenerative braking, which allows for recovering some energy and increasing range. Minimize extreme climate control usage, as systems like air conditioning can increase battery consumption. In the transition towards more sustainable mobility, analyzing the electric consumption of these vehicles is essential for promoting their use and developing adequate charging infrastructures.
